abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Cement Industry
            Modernization Project for Pakistan was unsatisfactory. The
            project achieved some of its objectives, its impact on
            institutional development was negligible, sustainability is
            uncertain at this time, and the performance of both the Bank
            and Borrower was satisfactory. Several lessons can be
            learned from this project. First, since significant
            implementation delays are more likely to be incurred for
            projects in the public sector, more weight should have been
            given in the SAR to the Bank's disbursement profile for
            the country. Second, continuity within the implementing
            agency is extremely important. Third, cumbersome channels
            for reporting and approval and lack of delegation caused
            significant delays in implementation. Fourth, procurement
            was very time consuming. The standardization of bidding
            documents, which has since been implemented in the Bank, is
            a major step towards streamlining the procurement process.
            It would have reduced the implementation time of the project
            considerably. Finally, the sharp focus and detailed analysis
            on the cement sub-sector during project preparation most
            likely induced GOP to decide on an early privatization of
            the cement sub-sector.
